results.title: A Summer's tale = Conte d'ete
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Canal+, Sofilmka, La Sept Cinema and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons”.
Gaspard (Melvil Poupard), a musically inclined maths graduate with time to kill is waiting for his girlfriend, Lena, in the resort town of Dinard, unbeknownst that his stable and uneventful life is about to be turned on it head when he becomes torn between his affections for three women. He whiles away the lazy afternoon hours with Margot (Amanda Langlet), a part time student and pancake house worker, and most importantly - a good listener. Margot wants a purely platonic relationship with Gaspard as she already has a boyfriend. Enter likely candidate number three, Margot’s friend Solene (Gwenaelle Simon), whom Gaspard becomes instantly smitten with and agrees to spend a weekend with on the island of Ouessant. When Lena finally arrives on the island Gaspard must finally make a choice between three women who are all offering him something different in the relationship stakes. In French with English subtitles. This film, the third in Rohmer’s “4 Season cycle” finds the director in fine story telling form.

results.title: A Winter's tale = Conte d'hiver
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons”.
Felicie’s love for Charles is undiminished four years after a romantic idyll during a summer holiday in Brittany but he has not contacted her - the home address she gave him was incorrect. In the meantime she has given birth to his daughter and is unable to choose between two adoring suitors. Rohmer, with more than a passing reference to Shakespeare, locates his customarily precise observation of the everyday complexities of human psychology in a tale of accident and coincidence. For Felice, the emotional aftermath of a lost summer is suspended or frozen until the thaw of a spring of promise. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Charlotte Very, Frederic Van Den Driessche and Michel Voletti.

results.title: A Tale of springtime = Conte de printemps
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons”.
The first in a series of films by Eric Rohmer based on the four seasons, “Le Conte de printemps” is essentially a chamber piece about the interaction of six characters (one of whom never appears). The characters are made up of three couples, whose centre is the developing friendship between the cerebral Jeanne and the instinctive Natasha. Rohmer’s visual style is restrained and unobtrusive, but also gloriously cinematic. There are flowers blooming everywhere, signs of rebirth, of hope, of the opportunites that life has to offer, and teasingly, the possibilities that lie just beyond the grasp of the flawed humanity that populates this film. Cast includes Anne Teyssedre, Hugues Quester, Florence Darel, Eloise Bennett, Sophie Robin.

results.brief_description: A series of programs in which Robyn Francis demonstrates permaculture techniques which can be applied to domestic gardens.

results.title: The Mandala garden
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Back yard permaculture”.
In less than four hours, permaculturist Robyn Francis transforms an area of vigorous lawn into a ready-to-plant, landscaped garden without the agonies of digging, turning the soil or removing the weeds. Vegetables, herbs and flowers are companion planted for ease of maintenance and harvest and in six weeks, the first delights of the garden are ready for picking. This gardening technique will suit any soil or climate.

results.title: The Burden of time
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Legacy”.
Central American civilisation developed quite independently from those of the rest of the world, yet bears striking resemblances to other great civilisations, from the great pyramids it built, and the invention of writing to the relationship of man, earth and the heavens, expressed in ritual and “the mathematics of eternity”. In spite of the disastrous past 500 years of history, the descendants of the Maya and the Aztecs have kept faith with their burden of time, through their shamen, and their blend of Christianity and the old religions, in spite of the pressures of western consumer society.

results.title: China: the mandate of heaven
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Legacy”.
China was the last of the great civilisations to develop independently, but it developed a vision of life unique to itself, centred on two quite separate philosophies - moral order, sustained by ritual, as taught by Confucius and the mysticism of Taoism, or the search for the”right way”. Chinese history is permeated by the search for harmony, and a belief in the self-sufficiency and order of Chinese culture, so that outside contact has been viewed as unnecessary and mostly discouraged - even to the present day.

results.title: Egypt: the habit of civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Legacy”.
The civilisation of ancient Egypt was conservative in nature, drawing its optimistic base from the annual flooding of the Nile which brought sustenance to the nation. The unchanging stability of the cosmos was symbolised by divine kingship, centralised power and the massive buildings which represented that power. The many surrendered power to the few - a condition which still exists for the majority of people today. Similarly almost everyone today, shares the ancient Egyptians’ concern for life after death. Yet the conquests of Alexander, and the synthesis of cultures which followed, culminating in the dominance of Islam have done little to change these basic beliefs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television, Central Productions and ITV

results.title: Iraq: cradle of civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Central Productions, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Legacy”.
Filmed just before and just after the Gulf War, the first program in this series looks at the effects of “civilisation” on the landscape, and the rise and fall of civilisations, particularly in relation to Iraq where civilisation began. The first cities were built 5000 years ago on the banks of the Euphrates in Southern Iraq, and city life soon transformed the human race with the glorious cultures of Mesopotamia such as Ur, Nineveh and Babylon. Michael Woods explores these ancient cultures and the legacy they gave to the history of Iraq right up to the Gulf War. The program is presented in two parts.
